results.title: Following their footsteps
results.brief_description: The small towns of Kernot and Grantville in south-eastern Victoria, depend on volunteer emergency services to ensure that when fires break out, car accidents happen or cats are stuck in trees, that someone is there to help. Who better to have on call than local legend Barrie Stewart and the dedicated members of the Kernot/Grantville CFA.

results.title: DAK: David Alexander Kopelman
results.brief_description: yDAK doesn’t consider himself an artist, he just “dabbles and makes stuff”. Despite this his scrap-metal sculptures and decorative gates can be found throughout the neighbourhoods, businesses and galleries of the Bass Coast in south-eastern Victoria. Cape Woolamai’s very own mo-hawked road warrior has a plasma cutter and he’s not afraid to use it!

results.title: The Bass Valley Community Centre
results.brief_description: When Clare Le Serve started a craft group for young mums in the early 1980s, she could not have imagined that it would grow over the next 30 years to become such an amazing community asset. With the help of local volunteers and paid staff, the Community Centre offers essential services that make a positive impact on the people of Bass and the surrounding Waterline region in south-eastern Victoria.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Bass Coast
results.brief_description: On Victoria’s south-eastern coastline, lie several scenic seaside towns. The residents of Phillip Island, San Remo, Corinella, Bass, Inverloch, Kernot and Grantville talk about how each town enriches their lives, through its distinct character and community spirit.

group_works.title: Life in the waves: a story about Island Surfboards

results.title: Life in the waves: a story about Island Surfboards
results.brief_description:
Sandy Ryan’s life revolves around surfing, helping his dad run ‘Island Surfboards’ on Phillip Island in south-eastern Victoria, and teaching others how to ride waves. Matt’s best mate and mentor, Glyndyn, is an ex-pro surfer that shapes boards for ‘Island Surfboards’ and doesn’t mind a surf either.
This is a story about a mateship, keeping it local and living the surfing lifestyle dream.

group.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Bass Coast

results.title: Community banking Bass Coast
results.brief_description: Early in 2001, the banks pulled out of the small coastal town of San Remo in south eastern Victoria, leaving the community with a challenge. Rather than sit on his hands and accept the inevitable consequences of downsizing, a local hardware store owner, Terry Ashenden, pulled together a committee of residents and business owners to overcome the problem.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: South west cinemas
results.brief_description: Take a front-seat tour of three regional Victorian cinemas, the Capitol in Warrnambool, the Lorne Theatre and the Portland Star. Your tour guides are the cinema staff, old and new, and the locals who frequent these historic cinemas and keep them alive. Despite highlighting the struggle to function commercially in the light of increased access through DVDs and downloadable films, the stories told, both colourful and romantic hint that the local cinema still has a place in people’s lives and how difficult it can be to replace the simple joy of the shared cinematic experience.

group_works.title: The Lorne Theatre
group_works.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

results.title: The Portland Star
results.brief_description: Local residents and theatre workers talk about the positive impact the Portland Star has made on their lives and reminisce about “rolling Jaffas down the aisle”. Even though the theatre has seen changes over the years, in 2008 offering live music as a means to keep going, the proprietor expresses his passion for the cinema, even when it sometimes runs at a loss, and why he will continue to serve the community with great movies and live events.

results.title: The Lorne Theatre
results.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Established over 90 years ago, the Lorne Theatre came about when a travelling picture show man ran out of funds and some local business men purchased his equipment and started running movies in the local hall. It then moved to its present site in 1937, where for such a small permanent population, the theatre has not changed much in all those years. Tony Hill, Manager of the Lorne Theatre, talks about the difficulties in offering a diverse range of cinema in the climate of DVDs and downloadable movies, and operating in a town prone to blackouts. He is proud the theatre is attended by a local group of cinephiles who sit in the same seat every session, and thinks himself very lucky to have his job.

results.title: Machines
results.creator_credit: Donald Mulholland, Fred Lasse and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
Minor carelessness in handling machinery may lead to a major accident. Investigating a fatal accident involving a power saw, the film reconstructs the steps leading up to the fatality and shows the worker’s two key mistakes in handling the saw.
